LabelType.caption: Age
LabelType.name: age
LabelType.Description: Age of data to process

LabelType.caption: Historical
LabelType.name: historical
LabelType.Description: Of or concerning history or past events

LabelType.caption: Medieval
LabelType.name: medieval
LabelType.Description: Relating to the Middle Ages.

LabelType.caption: Contemporary
LabelType.name: contemporary
LabelType.Description: Belonging to or occurring in the present

LabelType.caption: Ancient
LabelType.name: ancient
LabelType.Description: Belonging to the very distant past and no longer in existence.

LabelType.caption: Manual
LabelType.name: manual
LabelType.Description:
Human interaction required
Examples: Ground truthing
Related: Performance evaluation

LabelType.caption: Automated
LabelType.name: automated
LabelType.Description:
No interaction required
Examples: OCR
Related: Machine learning

LabelType.caption: Machine assisted / user-driven
LabelType.name: assisted
LabelType.Description:
Some automation, but user interaction possible / required
Examples: Auto-completion when typing
Related: Trainable, Interactive

LabelType.caption: Physical Production Method
LabelType.name: production-method
LabelType.Description: Production method of physical document (e.g. paper document such as a book)

LabelType.caption: Manual
LabelType.name: manual
LabelType.Description: E.g. handwritten

LabelType.caption: Typeset
LabelType.name: typeset
LabelType.Description: Printed using typesetting method

LabelType.caption: Computer printout
LabelType.name: computer
LabelType.Description: Printed from computer or other electronic device using an office or similar printer

LabelType.caption: Features
LabelType.name: features
LabelType.Description:
Extracted features
Examples: Word count of a text
Related: Information extraction, Machine learning

LabelType.caption: Structure
LabelType.name: structure
LabelType.Description:
Structure of an object of some sort
Examples: Document structure, Table structure

LabelType.caption: Table of contents
LabelType.name: toc
LabelType.Description: Table of contents of a book, newspaper etc.

LabelType.caption: Annotations
LabelType.name: annotations
LabelType.Description: Added data

LabelType.caption: Authorship
LabelType.name: authorship
LabelType.Description: Author attribution / information

LabelType.caption: Spatial
LabelType.name: spatial
LabelType.Description: Relating to space

LabelType.caption: Location
LabelType.name: location
LabelType.Description: Location or position

LabelType.caption: Settings
LabelType.name: settings
LabelType.Description: E.g. tool configuration

LabelType.caption: Model
LabelType.name: model
LabelType.Description:
A model for a concept.
Examples: Page model to aid recognition

LabelType.caption: Lexicon / index
LabelType.name: lexicon
LabelType.Description:
A collection of data items organised / sorted in a certain way.
Lexicon: the vocabulary of a person, language, or branch of knowledge

LabelType.caption: Corpus / database
LabelType.name: corpus
LabelType.Description:
Corpus: a collection of written texts, especially the entire works of a particular author or a body of writing on a particular subject.
Examples: A text corpus, An image database

LabelType.caption: Ground Truth / gold standard
LabelType.name: ground-truth
LabelType.Description: Ground truth is a term used in various fields to refer to information provided by direct observation as opposed to information provided by inference. Gold standard: the best available under reasonable conditions

LabelType.caption: Measured
LabelType.name: measured
LabelType.Description:
Measured (precise)
Examples: OCR performance measured using ground truth

LabelType.caption: Estimated
LabelType.name: estimated
LabelType.Description: Estimated by machine or human (not precise)

LabelType.caption: Random
LabelType.name: random
LabelType.Description:
Random data of some sort.
Examples: a random number between 1 and 6 (dice)

LabelType.caption: Fuzzy
LabelType.name: fuzzy
LabelType.Description: Statistical data are not always precise numbers, or vectors, or categories. Real data are frequently what is called fuzzy. Examples where this fuzziness is obvious are quality of life data, environmental, biological, medical, sociological and economics data. Also the results of measurements can be best described by using fuzzy numbers and fuzzy vectors respectively.

LabelType.caption: Licence
LabelType.name: license
LabelType.Description: Software or data usage licence

LabelType.caption: Non-commercial
LabelType.name: non-commercial
LabelType.Description: Free for non-commercial use

LabelType.caption: Open Source
LabelType.name: openSource
LabelType.Description:
Open-source software (OSS) is computer software with its source code made available with a license in which the copyright holder provides the rights to study, change, and distribute the software to anyone and for any purpose.
Related: Free / paid for

LabelType.caption: Platform
LabelType.name: platform
LabelType.Description: Supported platform

LabelType.caption: Web
LabelType.name: web
LabelType.Description: Web service or web app

LabelType.caption: Annotated
LabelType.name: annotated
LabelType.Description: Textual content with annotations

LabelType.caption: Natural language
LabelType.name: natural-language
LabelType.Description:
Text represents natural language.
Examples: A news artcile
Related:

LabelType.caption: Structured
LabelType.name: structured
LabelType.Description: E.g. XML

LabelType.caption: Tabular
LabelType.name: tabular
LabelType.Description:
Content encoded in tabular form
Examples: A tab-separated table with headings and values

LabelType.caption: Vector-based
LabelType.name: vector-based
LabelType.Description: E.g. polygonal

LabelType.caption: Stroke-based
LabelType.name: stroke-based
LabelType.Description: Examples: Online handwriting

LabelType.caption: Activity Domain
LabelType.name: activityDomain
LabelType.Description:
General domain, research field or specific processing strategy of a workflow activty.
Examples: An activity for automated number plate recognition could be labelled with "OCR" domain.
Related: "Topic" of a data object

LabelType.caption: Computing
LabelType.name: computing
LabelType.Description:
Computing is any goal-oriented activity requiring, benefiting from, or creating a mathematical sequence of steps known as an algorithm — e.g. through computers.
Examples: Any activity in document image analysis is from the domain of computing. Only steps such as physical document restoration should be excluded.
Related: Data object "topic" such as Engineering

LabelType.caption: Visual Computing
LabelType.name: visual
LabelType.Description:
Visual computing is a generic term for all computer science disciplines handling with images and 3D models, i.e. computer graphics, image processing, visualization, computer vision, virtual and augmented reality, video processing, but also includes aspects of pattern recognition, human computer interaction, machine learning and digital libraries.
Examples: See above
Related: "Machine Learning" (separate label type)

LabelType.caption: Image and video processing
LabelType.name: imgVidProc
LabelType.Description:
Image processing is processing of images using mathematical operations by using any form of signal processing for which the input is an image, a series of images, or a video, such as a photograph or video frame. Video processing is a particular case of signal processing, which often employs video filters and where the input and output signals are video files or video streams.
Examples: Binarisation of a colour image
Related: Content analysis (for information extraction) Computer graphics (for visualisation)

LabelType.caption: Geometric image/video processing
LabelType.name: geometric
LabelType.Description:
Affine transsformation or other geometric operation applied to an image / video. An affine transformation is an important class of linear 2-D geometric transformations which maps variables (e.g. pixel intensity values located at position Eqn:eqnxy1 in an input image) into new variables (e.g. Eqn:eqnxy2 in an output image) by applying a linear combination of translation, rotation, scaling and/or shearing (i.e. non-uniform scaling in some directions) operations.
Examples: Rotation, dewarping
Related: Pixel-based operations

LabelType.caption: Pixel-based image/video processing
LabelType.name: pixel-based
LabelType.Description:
Any image operation on pixel-level
Examples: Binarisation, morphological operations
Related: Geometric processing

LabelType.caption: Content analysis and recognition
LabelType.name: analysisRecognition
LabelType.Description:
Content analysis is "a wide and heterogeneous set of manual or computer-assisted techniques for contextualized interpretations of documents produced by communication processes in the strict sense of that phrase (any kind of text, written, iconic, multimedia, etc.) or signification processes (traces and artifacts), having as ultimate goal the production of valid and trustworthy inferences."
Examples: Text recognition / OCR
Related: Text processing (separate categoty) Performance evaluation (separate categoty)

LabelType.caption: Text and symbol recognition
LabelType.name: text
LabelType.Description:
Translation of any kind of depicted symbols to machine readable format
Examples: OCR Mathematical equation recognition
Related: Text processing (separate category) Table recognition Map reading

LabelType.caption: OCR
LabelType.name: ocr
LabelType.Description:
Optical character recognition (optical character reader, OCR) is the mechanical or electronic conversion of images of typed, handwritten or printed text into machine-encoded text, whether from a scanned document, a photo of a document, a scene-photo (for example the text on signs and billboards in a landscape photo) or from subtitle text superimposed on an image (for example from a television broadcast).
Examples: Number plate reading
Related: Mathematical equation recognition Map reading

LabelType.caption: Mathematical expression recognition
LabelType.name: maths
LabelType.Description:
Specialised recognition of mathematical equations / formulas.
Examples: Equations in scientific papers
Related: OCR

LabelType.caption: Date recognition
LabelType.name: date
LabelType.Description:
Specialised recognition of dates and times
Examples: Date printed on newspaper page
Related: OCR

LabelType.caption: Table / form analysis and recognition
LabelType.name: tables
LabelType.Description:
The recognition of table/form structure and/or contents.
Examples: Stock exchange data in a newspaper, Filled in questionaire form
Related: OCR Object / shape recognition (e.g. table separator detection)

LabelType.caption: Chart recognition
LabelType.name: charts
LabelType.Description:
Recognition or analysis of data charts.
Examples: Pie chart, Bar chart, Graphs
Related: OCR, Object / shape recognition

LabelType.caption: Map and plan reading
LabelType.name: maps
LabelType.Description:
Recognition and analysis of maps or plans of any kind.
Examples: Floor plans, Engineering drawings, Geographical maps
Related: OCR, Object / shape recognition

LabelType.caption: Object / shape recognition
LabelType.name: shape
LabelType.Description:
Object recognition is a process for identifying a specific object in a digital image or video. Object recognition algorithms rely on matching, learning, or pattern recognition algorithms using appearance-based or feature-based techniques. Common techniques include edges, gradients, Histogram of Oriented Gradients (HOG), Haar wavelets, and linear binary patterns.
Examples: Logo recognition Fingerprint reading
Related: Machine learning, Text and symbol recognition Forensic studies

LabelType.caption: Face recognition
LabelType.name: face
LabelType.Description:
A facial recognition system is a computer application capable of identifying or verifying a person from a digital image or a video frame from a video source. One of the ways to do this is by comparing selected facial features from the image and a facial database.
Examples: Smartphone unlocking via detection of owner's face
Related: Machine learning (separate category)

LabelType.caption: Layout analysis
LabelType.name: layoutAnalysis
LabelType.Description:
In computer vision, document layout analysis is the process of identifying and categorizing the regions of interest in the scanned image of a text document. A reading system requires the segmentation of text zones from non-textual ones and the arrangement in their correct reading order.
Examples: Page layout analysis (segmentation into regions, classification into text, graphic, table etc.)
Related: "OCR": Often used as a synonym for layout analysis and text recognition, but strictly only the text recognition component.

LabelType.caption: Computer graphics
LabelType.name: graphics
LabelType.Description:
Computer graphics are pictures and movies created using computers - usually referring to image data created by a computer specifically with help from specialized graphical hardware and software.
Example: Text rendering
Related: Presentation / visualisation (part of Data Creation / Transformation)

LabelType.caption: Text processing
LabelType.name: text
LabelType.Description:
In computing, the term text processing refers to the discipline of mechanizing the creation or manipulation of electronic text. Text usually refers to all the alphanumeric characters specified on the keyboard of the person performing the mechanization, but in general text here means the abstraction layer that is one layer above the standard character encoding of the target text. The term processing refers to automated (or mechanized) processing, as opposed to the same manipulation done manually.
Text processing involves computer commands which invoke content, content changes, and cursor movement, for example to - search and replace - format - generate a processed report of the content of, or - filter a file or report of a text file.
Related: Text recognition (Visual Computing)

LabelType.caption: Natural language processing
LabelType.name: naturalLanguage
LabelType.Description:
Natural language processing (NLP) is a field of computer science, artificial intelligence, and computational linguistics concerned with the interactions between computers and human (natural) languages. As such, NLP is related to the area of human–computer interaction. Many challenges in NLP involve: natural language understanding, enabling computers to derive meaning from human or natural language input; and others involve natural language generation.
Examples: Digitial assistents (e.g. in smartphones)
Related: OCR

LabelType.caption: Language identification
LabelType.name: identification
LabelType.Description:
In natural language processing, language identification or language guessing is the problem of determining which natural language given content is in.
Examples: Language identification to select a dictionary for OCR applications
Related: OCR

LabelType.caption: Sentiment mining
LabelType.name: sentiment
LabelType.Description:
Sentiment analysis (also known as opinion mining) refers to the use of natural language processing, text analysis and computational linguistics to identify and extract subjective information in source materials.
Examples: A basic task in sentiment analysis is classifying the polarity of a given text at the document, sentence, or feature/aspect level — whether the expressed opinion in a document, a sentence or an entity feature/aspect is positive, negative, or neutral.
Related: Summarising

LabelType.caption: Summarising
LabelType.name: summarising
LabelType.Description:
Automatic summarization is the process of reducing a text document with a computer program in order to create a summary that retains the most important points of the original document. Technologies that can make a coherent summary take into account variables such as length, writing style and syntax.
Examples: Automatic summary of a news article
Related: Sentiment mining

LabelType.caption: Part-of-speech tagging
LabelType.name: partOfSpeech
LabelType.Description:
In corpus linguistics, part-of-speech tagging (POS tagging or POST), also called grammatical tagging or word-category disambiguation, is the process of marking up a word in a text (corpus) as corresponding to a particular part of speech, based on both its definition and its context—i.e., its relationship with adjacent and related words in a phrase, sentence, or paragraph.
Examples: A simplified form of this is commonly taught to school-age children, in the identification of words as nouns, verbs, adjectives, adverbs, etc.
Related: Named entitiy recognition, Tokenisation (as part of Data creation / transformation)

LabelType.caption: Named entity recognition
LabelType.name: namedEntities
LabelType.Description:
Named-entity recognition (NER) (also known as entity identification, entity chunking and entity extraction) is a subtask of information extraction that seeks to locate and classify named entities in text into pre-defined categories such as the names of persons, organizations, locations, expressions of times, quantities, monetary values, percentages, etc.
Related: Part-of-speech tagging Summarising

LabelType.caption: Machine learning
LabelType.name: machineLearning
LabelType.Description:
Machine learning is a subfield of computer science[1] that evolved from the study of pattern recognition and computational learning theory in artificial intelligence. In 1959, Arthur Samuel defined machine learning as a "Field of study that gives computers the ability to learn without being explicitly programmed". Machine learning explores the study and construction of algorithms that can learn from and make predictions on data.
Examples: Decision tree learning, Artificial neural networks
Related: Content analysis and recognition

LabelType.caption: Information Management
LabelType.name: informationManagement
LabelType.Description:
Information management (IM) concerns a cycle of organisational activity: the acquisition of information from one or more sources, the custodianship and the distribution of that information to those who need it, and its ultimate disposition through archiving or deletion. Data management comprises all the disciplines related to managing data as a valuable resource.
Examples: Data access, Data security Document management system
Related: Visualistation (as part of Data Creation / Transformation)

LabelType.caption: Data retrieval
LabelType.name: retrieval
LabelType.Description:
Data retrieval means obtaining data from a database management system such as ODBMS. In this case, it is considered that data is represented in a structured way, and there is no ambiguity in data. In order to retrieve the desired data the user present a set of criteria by a query.
Examples: Retrieval of image from image database using pattern matching
Related: Visualisation

LabelType.caption: Performance evaluation
LabelType.name: performanceEval
LabelType.Description:
Measuring the performance of a given software system or method, returning for instance a quality value.
Examples: OCR accuracy measurement
Related: Information extraction Pattern matching

LabelType.caption: Comparative performance analysis
LabelType.name: comparative
LabelType.Description:
Basic comparison of software systems or methods to decide which is better under given circumstances.
Examples: Number of correctly recognised words of two OCR engines
Related: Information extraction Ground truth

LabelType.caption: In-depth performance analysis
LabelType.name: in-depth
LabelType.Description:
Performance analysis providing detail on the evaluation result in order to be able to understand the result and improve the methods / systems under investigation.
Examples: Region-based layout analysis performance with merges, splits, misses, false detections etc., OCR accuracy with recognition statistics per character class
Related: Information retrieval

LabelType.caption: Forensic studies
LabelType.name: forensics
LabelType.Description:
Forensic science is the application of science to criminal and civil laws. Forensic scientists collect, preserve, and analyze scientific evidence during the course of an investigation.
Examples: Document verification / counterfeit detection
Related: Face recognition

LabelType.caption: Processing Level
LabelType.name: processingLevel
LabelType.Description: Distinction between low-level data processing (e.g. using a mathematical formula) and high-level processing that entails some form of recognition, reasoning or matching.

LabelType.caption: Low-level processing
LabelType.name: low-level
LabelType.Description:
Data processing involving basic conversion, application of mathematical formulas or similar
Examples: Image thresholding Image smoothing Text chunking (e.g. splitting into words)
Related: Several visual computing approaches

LabelType.caption: High-level processing
LabelType.name: high-level
LabelType.Description:
Processing that entails some form of recognition, reasoning or matching, for example.
Examples: OCR Face recognition
Related: Natural language processing, Content analysis and recognition

LabelType.caption: Detection / Identification
LabelType.name: detection
LabelType.Description:
Methods involving some form of detection, identification, location or matching.
Examples: Writer identification, Logo detection
Related: Object recognition, OCR, Machine learning

LabelType.caption: Verification / authentication
LabelType.name: verification
LabelType.Description:
Authentication (from Greek: αὐθεντικός authentikos, "real, genuine", from αὐθέντης authentes, "author") is the act of confirming the truth of an attribute of a single piece of data (a datum) claimed true by an entity. In contrast with identification which refers to the act of stating or otherwise indicating a claim purportedly attesting to a person or thing's identity, authentication is the process of actually confirming that identity.
Examples: Signature verification
Related: Forensic studies, Content analysis and recognition

LabelType.caption: Classification / recognition
LabelType.name: classification
LabelType.Description:
In machine learning and statistics, classification is the problem of identifying to which of a set of categories (sub-populations) a new observation belongs, on the basis of a training set of data containing observations (or instances) whose category membership is known.
Pattern recognition is a branch of machine learning that focuses on the recognition of patterns and regularities in data, although it is in some cases considered to be nearly synonymous with machine learning.
Examples: OCR
Related: Machine learning, Content analysis and recognition

LabelType.caption: Understanding
LabelType.name: understanding
LabelType.Description:
Highest level of processing including reasoning based on the actual meaning of the data that is beaing processed.
Examples: Natural language understanding
Related: Machine learning, Content analysis and recognition, Natural language processing

LabelType.caption: Data Creation / Transformation
LabelType.name: dataTransformation
LabelType.Description:
Any action to creates or transforms data.
Examples: Image acquisition, conversion, Text tokenisation, Annotation, Extraction

LabelType.caption: Acquisition
LabelType.name: acquisition
LabelType.Description:
Data acquisition is the process of sampling signals that measure real world physical conditions and converting the resulting samples into digital numeric values that can be manipulated by a computer. Data acquisition systems, abbreviated by the acronyms DAS or DAQ, typically convert analog waveforms into digital values for processing. The components of data acquisition systems include:
Sensors, to convert physical parameters to electrical signals. Signal conditioning circuitry, to convert sensor signals into a form that can be converted to digital values. Analog-to-digital converters, to convert conditioned sensor signals to digital values.
Related: Conversion Retrieval

LabelType.caption: Conversion
LabelType.name: conversion
LabelType.Description:
Data conversion is the conversion of computer data from one format to another.
Examples: JPG image to PNG image, UTF-8 encoded text to ASCII
Related: Low-level processing

LabelType.caption: Segmentation / tokenisation
LabelType.name: segmentation
LabelType.Description:
Splitting data into distinct parts or demarking the points where to split.
Examples: Document page segmentation, Image segmentation, Foreground-background separation, Text tokeinsation / chunking
Related: Content analysis / recognition Annotation / labelling

LabelType.caption: Enhancement
LabelType.name: enhancement
LabelType.Description:
Removal of unwanted parts of data or adding/correcting data to improve readability, quality. Pre- or postprocessing of some kind.
Examples: Noise removal in images, Geometric correction, Spelling correction, Watermark removal, Text restoration
Related: Low-level processing

LabelType.caption: Enrichment
LabelType.name: enrichment
LabelType.Description:
Adding data to increase information content
Examples: Adding metadata
Related: Part-of-speech tagging

LabelType.caption: Annotation / labelling
LabelType.name: annotation
LabelType.Description:
Localised addition of information.
Examples: Part-of-speech tagging, Named entitiy tagging, Page layout annotation (regions etc.)
Related: Segmentation

LabelType.caption: Information extraction
LabelType.name: extraction
LabelType.Description:
Information extraction (IE) is the task of automatically extracting structured information from unstructured and/or semi-structured machine-readable documents. In most of the cases this activity concerns processing human language texts by means of natural language processing (NLP).
Examples: Language and vocabulary analysis, Image understanding
Related: High-level processing Content analysis and recognition

LabelType.caption: Visualisation / presentation
LabelType.name: visualisation
LabelType.Description:
Information visualisation is the study of (interactive) visual representations of abstract data to reinforce human cognition. The abstract data include both numerical and non-numerical data, such as text and geographic information.
Examples: Text rendering Chart creation
Related: Conversion Computer graphics

LabelType.caption: Adaptability / Applicability
LabelType.name: adaptability
LabelType.Description:
How well can the activity adapt to different circumstances.
Examples: Trainable method, Interactive system

LabelType.caption: Configurable
LabelType.name: configurable
LabelType.Description:
A method that can be configured in some way to allow the explicit adaption to different use cases.
Examples: OCR with settings for language, font etc.
Related: Interactive Generic / unconstraint

LabelType.caption: Trainable
LabelType.name: trainable
LabelType.Description:
A method that can be trained by examples.
Examples: OCR training to support a new type of font
Related: Configurable, Interactive, Generic / unconstraint

LabelType.caption: Supervised
LabelType.name: supervised
LabelType.Description:
Supervised learning is the machine learning task of inferring a function from labeled training data.[1] The training data consist of a set of training examples. In supervised learning, each example is a pair consisting of an input object (typically a vector) and a desired output value (also called the supervisory signal). A supervised learning algorithm analyzes the training data and produces an inferred function, which can be used for mapping new examples.
Examples: Labelled character images for training an OCR engine
Related: Configurable Interactive

LabelType.caption: Unsupervised
LabelType.name: unsupervised
LabelType.Description:
Unsupervised learning is the machine learning task of inferring a function to describe hidden structure from unlabeled data. Since the examples given to the learner are unlabeled, there is no error or reward signal to evaluate a potential solution. This distinguishes unsupervised learning from supervised learning and reinforcement learning.
Examples: Clustering
Related: Machine learning

LabelType.caption: Interactive
LabelType.name: interactive
LabelType.Description:
A method that adapts according to user interaction.
Examples: Dictionary expansion during spell checking
Related: Configurable, Trainable

LabelType.caption: Generic / unconstraint
LabelType.name: generic
LabelType.Description:
Method with wide applicability which therefore may not need to be trained or configured.
Examples: Google multi-language OCR
Related: Trainable, Configurable

LabelType.caption: Maturity
LabelType.name: maturity
LabelType.Description:
System / method/ algorithm maturity.
Examples: Prototype, Production system
Related: Licence

LabelType.caption: Stable
LabelType.name: stable
LabelType.Description: A stable release is available

LabelType.caption: Experimental
LabelType.name: experimental
LabelType.Description: Experimental, in development, prototype

LabelType.caption: Industrial
LabelType.name: industrial
LabelType.Description: Production-strengh method / system that is reliable, tested, and robust

LabelType.caption: Original Source
LabelType.name: originalSource
LabelType.Description: Disregarding the current form of the data, where does it originate from, what was the original medium?

LabelType.caption: Produced data
LabelType.name: produced
LabelType.Description:
Data that has been composed, created, produced or rendered in some form.
Examples: Book, Website
Related: Content Encoding

LabelType.caption: Physical source medium
LabelType.name: physical
LabelType.Description:
The data was orininally part of a physical medium
Examples: Newspaper Whiteboard writing
Related: Physical production method

LabelType.caption: Paper document
LabelType.name: paper
LabelType.Description:
The data was orignially produced on paper
Example: Printed magazine
Related: Age

LabelType.caption: Book
LabelType.name: book
LabelType.Description:
A paper book
Examples: Notebook, Novel
Related: Physical production method

LabelType.caption: Newspaper
LabelType.name: newspaper
LabelType.Description:
A printed newspaper
Examples: The Guardian
Related: Physical production method

LabelType.caption: Magazine
LabelType.name: magazine
LabelType.Description:
A printed magazine.
Usyually with more complex layout and formatting in comparison to books or newspapers.
Examples: Time magazine
Related: Physical production method

LabelType.caption: Journal
LabelType.name: journal
LabelType.Description:
A printed journal
Examples: Science journal
Related: Physical production method

LabelType.caption: Whiteboard / blackboard
LabelType.name: whiteboard
LabelType.Description:
The data was originally produced on a whiteboard / flipchart / blackboard
Examples: Whiteboard bullet points from a meeting
Related: Physical production method

LabelType.caption: Poster
LabelType.name: poster
LabelType.Description:
A poster or board of some kind
Examples: A poster for a research paper
Related: Physical production method

LabelType.caption: Virtual source medium
LabelType.name: virtual
LabelType.Description:
The data was created in / for the virtual space (digital)
Examples: Word processor document
Related: Content encoding

LabelType.caption: World Wide Web
LabelType.name: www
LabelType.Description:
The data was created for the Internet.
Examples: Wikipedia page
Related: Data conversion, Visualisation

LabelType.caption: Captured data
LabelType.name: captured
LabelType.Description:
Data captured from the real world / the environment
Examples: Photograph of a street
Related: Acquisition

LabelType.caption: Real / natural scenes
LabelType.name: scenes
LabelType.Description:
Scenes captured from the world
Examples: A picture of a room with people
Related: Acquisition

LabelType.caption: 3D scenes
LabelType.name: 3D
LabelType.Description: Threedimensional scenes captured somehow

LabelType.caption: Acquisition / Replication Method
LabelType.name: acquisition
LabelType.Description:
Involved methods that lead from the source medium to the current state / format
Examples: Scanning, Photocopying
Related: Physical production method, Source medium

LabelType.caption: Analog / physical to digital
LabelType.name: analogToDigital
LabelType.Description:
Conversion from any form of analog or physical data / medium to digital form.
Examples: Digital photography, Scanning
Related: Source medium

LabelType.caption: Scanning
LabelType.name: scanning
LabelType.Description:
Capturing with digital scanner
Examples: Flatbed scanner
Related: Acquisition

LabelType.caption: Camera
LabelType.name: camera
LabelType.Description:
Camera-based digitisation
Examples: Overhead scanner, Smartphone document capture
Related: Acquisition method

LabelType.caption: Copied
LabelType.name: copied
LabelType.Description: Replicated in some way

LabelType.caption: Photocopy
LabelType.name: photocopy
LabelType.Description: A document that was photocopied at some point

LabelType.caption: Carbon copy
LabelType.name: carbon-copy
LabelType.Description: The document is a carbon copy

LabelType.caption: Microfilm / microfiche
LabelType.name: microfilm
LabelType.Description: The document copied to microfilm or microfiche at some point

LabelType.caption: Faxed
LabelType.name: fax
LabelType.Description: The document was faxed (using a fax machine)

LabelType.caption: Synthesis
LabelType.name: synthesis
LabelType.Description:
The combination of components or elements to form a connected whole
Examples: Artificial ground truth (e.g. a synthetic newspaper page)
Related: Acquisition Source medium

LabelType.caption: Content of Interest
LabelType.name: contentOfInterest
LabelType.Description: Source / target content. What is the intersting bit in the data at hand.

LabelType.caption: Barcode / QR code
LabelType.name: barcode
LabelType.Description:
A barcode is a machine-readable representation of data relating to the object to which it is attached. Originally barcodes systematically represented data by varying the widths and spacings of parallel lines, and may be referred to as linear or one-dimensional (1D). Later two-dimensional (2D) codes were developed, using rectangles, dots, hexagons and other geometric patterns in two dimensions, usually called barcodes although they do not use bars as such. Barcodes originally were scanned by special optical scanners called barcode readers. Later applications software became available for devices that could read images, such as smartphones with cameras.
Examples: - Barcode on a product - QR code representing a weblink

LabelType.caption: Physical / visual granularity
LabelType.name: physical
LabelType.Description: E.g. segmentation

LabelType.caption: Region / Zone
LabelType.name: region
LabelType.Description: Region, zone, block

LabelType.caption: Word
LabelType.name: word
LabelType.Description: Word or partial word, if separated by line break, for example

LabelType.caption: Glyph
LabelType.name: glyph
LabelType.Description: In typography, a glyph is an elemental symbol within an agreed set of symbols, intended to represent a readable character for the purposes of writing

LabelType.caption: Double-page
LabelType.name: double-page
LabelType.Description: Two facing pages (e.g. in book)

LabelType.caption: Document
LabelType.name: document
LabelType.Description:
A complete document
Examples: Book

LabelType.caption: Table
LabelType.name: table
LabelType.Description: A table with columns and rows

LabelType.name: column
LabelType.Description: Table column

LabelType.caption: Row
LabelType.name: row
LabelType.Description: Table row

LabelType.caption: Cell
LabelType.name: cell
LabelType.Description: Table cell

LabelType.caption: Data Condition
LabelType.name: condition
LabelType.Description: Degradation, aging, damage etc.

LabelType.caption: Speckles
LabelType.name: speckles
LabelType.Description: Speckle-like noise

LabelType.caption: Salt-and-pepper noise
LabelType.name: salt-and-pepper
LabelType.Description: Small, bright and dark dot-like noise

LabelType.caption: Clutter
LabelType.name: clutter
LabelType.Description: Larger noise 'objects'

LabelType.caption: Thresholding related noise
LabelType.name: thresholding-related
LabelType.Description: Image thresholding / binarisation-related noise

LabelType.caption: Production-related
LabelType.name: production-related
LabelType.Description: Conditions introduced during the production of the medium / object

LabelType.caption: Document characteristics
LabelType.name: document-characteristics
LabelType.Description: Document-related charactersitics

LabelType.caption: Pasted clippings
LabelType.name: pasted-clippings
LabelType.Description: Paper clippings pasted onto a page

LabelType.caption: Textured paper
LabelType.name: textured-paper
LabelType.Description: Paper with a visible texture

LabelType.caption: Uneven character spacing
LabelType.name: uneven-character-spacing
LabelType.Description: Intra-word and inter-word character spacing is not uniform

LabelType.caption: Narrow border
LabelType.name: narrow-border
LabelType.Description: The content of a page reaches very close to the page border or even touches it

LabelType.caption: Low paper-to-content contrast
LabelType.name: low-contrast
LabelType.Description: The contrast bwtween the paper and the page content is very low

LabelType.caption: Halftoning
LabelType.name: halftoning
LabelType.Description: Dot-based halftoning printing technique was used (to emulate more colours / grey tones)

LabelType.caption: Dithering
LabelType.name: dithering
LabelType.Description: Dithering printing technique was used (added randomness to avoid unwanted patterns)

LabelType.caption: Document faults
LabelType.name: document-faults
LabelType.Description: Fault introduced during document production

LabelType.caption: Bleed-through
LabelType.name: bleed-through
LabelType.Description: Ink bled through from back of page

LabelType.caption: Ink from facing page
LabelType.name: ink-from-facing
LabelType.Description: Ink from facing page was transferred to this page

LabelType.caption: Smeared ink
LabelType.name: smeared-ink
LabelType.Description: Ink was smeared after printing / writing

LabelType.caption: Touching characters
LabelType.name: touching-chars
LabelType.Description: Independent characters are touching due to printing issues

LabelType.caption: Horizontally touching characters
LabelType.name: horizontally
LabelType.Description: Neighbouring characters within one text line are touching

LabelType.caption: Vertically touching characters
LabelType.name: vertically
LabelType.Description: Characters from neighbouring text lines are touching each other

LabelType.caption: Uneven ink distribution
LabelType.name: uneven-ink-distrib
LabelType.Description: The ink was not distributed properly during printing, leading to unwanted empty or faint regions

LabelType.caption: Filled-in characters
LabelType.name: filled-in-chars
LabelType.Description: Gaps or holes in characters are filled in (e.g. due to too much ink)

LabelType.caption: Sort shoulder artefacts
LabelType.name: sort-shoulder-artefacts
LabelType.Description: Sort shoulder parts touched the paper during printing, leading to visible artefacts around characters

LabelType.caption: Broken characters
LabelType.name: broken-chars
LabelType.Description: Some print characters were broken (bits missing) leading to repeated visible defects

LabelType.caption: Faint characters
LabelType.name: faint-chars
LabelType.Description: Faint individual characters, e.g. when not using enough force during typewriting

LabelType.caption: Blurred characters
LabelType.name: blurred-chars
LabelType.Description: Blurred characters due to production issues

LabelType.caption: Non-straight text lines
LabelType.name: non-straight-text-lines
LabelType.Description: Text lines were not printed straight (printing issue / limitation)

LabelType.Description: The medium (e.g. paper) is damaged in some way

LabelType.caption: Clear tape

LabelType.caption: Informative additions

LabelType.caption: Corrections
